loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
“Try and try until you succeed.” This is the guiding principle of Elena, a 32-year-old businesswoman. She is married to Jonar, a passenger jeepney operator in their village. A jeepney is a popular means of public transportation in the Philippines. 

The couple has two young children. Their eldest is presently studying in elementary school and their youngest is just a year old. Their family lives in the village of Ballacong, Ilagan, Isabela. Elena wants a good future for her two children. By engaging in business, she hopes to support the growing needs of her two angels. 

Elena started managing her general store when she got married. She wanted to earn income for her family, most especially for her children. Elena is requesting her 10th loan. She will use the loan as additional capital to continuously improve and expand her retailing business. With the help of the loan, she will be able to purchase more items to sell.

loans.use: Buying grocery items for her retail store

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Mario is engaged in a hog raising business. Aside from this, he also sells ice candy in the village where he lives. Mario has been a client of ASKI for nearly a year and he started his businesses when he became part of ASKI. The ice candies that he sells are made by his wife and serve as their daily source of income. He hopes that both his businesses will continuously grow with the help of KIVA lenders. 

Mario is requesting a loan of Php8,000 to further expand his businesses. With this amount, he could purchase stocks of feed for his hogs and make more ice candy as well. He hopes that his loan request will be approved.

Mario is a 49-year-old businessman. His family lives in the village of San Lorenzo, Ilagan, Isabela. His wife, Iponela, patiently produces ice candies to support their daily needs. They work hard together to sustain their needs.

loans.use: Additional capital for his hog raising business and ice candy vending business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth S. is from the village of Iligan City. She is 52 years old. Elizabeth is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Elizabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma S. is from the city of Oroquieta. She is 55 years old. Norma is married and has 4 adult children. Norma owns a business buying and selling coconuts.  Norma has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos (about $171 US) a month for these activities.

In 2005, Norma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norma has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Norma is requesting a new loan of 12,000 pesos which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Norma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda J. is from the village of Dalipuga, Iligan City. She is 49 years old. Melinda is separated from her spouse and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Melinda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Melinda has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Melinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Melinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Melinda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Melinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe D. C. manages a general store. She is 56 years old and married to Domingo D. C.. The couple is blessed with five children, and four of them are college graduate and have their own jobs. The couple strives hard to send their children to a higher level of education. They are thankful because, through the business they manage, they are able to support their children during their school days.

Fe would like to continue improving her store for their financial security as they grow older. In this regard, she would like to ask for additional capital from the Kiva lenders amounting to PHP5,000 for expansion and buying additional groceries for her store. She would be glad if this amount is given.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy groceries for her store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Nestor

texts.en:
Motorcycle transport is the primary source of income of Nestor and his wife in the village of Barangay Calamagui, San Pablo, Isabela, Cagayan. Aside from his transport business, Nestor is also engaged in farming while Sonia, his wife, sometimes sells cosmetic products in their village to earn extra income.

For the continuous development of their transport business, Nestor is again requesting a loan of Php 7,000 from lenders. He hopes that his loan will again be approved to enable him to repair his motorcycle. Aside from that he will also utilize some amount of the loan for his farming needs.

The couple is working double time for the welfare of their children. They hope that their children will finish their college degrees.

loans.use: To repair his motorcycle and for farming needs

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en: Chhum S. P. is a 28-year-old married mother caring for a child who is a student in the local public school. For nine years, Chhum S. P. has worked sewing clothes for the garment industry and she earns a salary at least of $100 a month to help pay her family’s living expenses. Her husband is a local carpenter who builds wooden furniture for sale. Presently, Chhum S. P. doesn’t have a vehicle and so she finds it hard to travel anywhere. Therefore, Chhum S. P. requested a loan of US$1200 to be used to buy a new motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Joel

texts.en: Joel is a 28-year-old single man living in the peaceful Barangay (village) of San Roque, Enrile, Cagayan. Joel is well known in the village as a good  and friendly neighbor.  Joel is engaged in beauty services. He offers manicures, pedicures, and hair cutting and he earns a daily income of PHP250.00. He has two workers in his salon. Joel wants to obtain a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP 7,000.00 to invest in his business and for the education of his niece. He hopes and prays that KIVA lenders will grant his loan in order for him to have a productive business.

loans.use: To invest in a beauty salon.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios is 61 years old and a resident of Gampis, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is married and blessed with five children. Her husband has no income because he has been disabled since they were married. Their children are all in school and the school miscellaneous expenditures and the school tuition fees have been increased.

Remedios finds ways on her own to support her husband and her family. She owns a small carinderia (restaurant) that she started with a small amount of capital. She has been an active member of Paglaum since October 2009 and is thankful that Paglaum came to their place because she believes that it can help to put up additional capital for her business, while she also enjoys the programs and services it offers.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her carinderia

loans.name: Annet Nalubega‘S Group

texts.en:
Annet is a 62-year-old married woman with six children aged between 25 and 40 years. None of her children goes to school, but her grandchildren do. She owns a seven-roomed house where she resides with three people. Annet takes care of additional family members.The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

Annet works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a stall selling bunches and clusters of bananas in Ntinda Kigowa Zone. Annet works seven days a week, selling both retail and wholesale. She receives an average of 20 customers a day. Her major business challenges include defaulters and the ever-increasing price of bananas due to persistent drought in banana-growing areas. Her monthly expenses include water and electricity bills, feeding the family, and transportation to and from Nakawa Market, where she buys bananas.

Annet has been in this business for over 28 years and with MCDT for 10 years, servicing her 23 loans working with the same group mates. Annet joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because of working in the group.She wants to use her part of this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more bananas for sale

loans.name: Pablita

texts.en:
Pablita P. is from the municipality of Mohon, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 64 years old, married, and has four adult children.

In 2003, Pablita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC and is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase coconuts. This loan will be her tenth from PMPC.

Pablita plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business in the market. She has been in this kind of business for over thirty years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

loans.use: To purchase more coconuts

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok P. is taking out her first loan to purchase a piece of farmland in a good location on which she will grow different kinds of crop. In addition, she will rent her land out to other farmers for a fee. She is 45 years old and married. She and her husband are local cultivators. They have three children: two are married and one is still young. Two of the children are employed in various occupations. This couple currently generates an income of approximately $5 per day from their business.

loans.use: To purchase a piece of farmland

loans.name: Janet Nakabugo's Group

texts.en:
Janet owns a restaurant selling all types of food near the main hospital (Mulago), in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She sells both retail and wholesale. Janet works seven days a week. She serves an average of 25 customers a day. Her major business challenges include thieves, the ever increasing prices of foodstuffs due to the persistent drought in banana-growing areas, and the rainy season which hinders her customers from reaching her. She incurs additional transport costs buying foodstuff from Kalerwe market (one of the busiest markets in Uganda).

Janet is 40. None of her children go to school, only her grandchildren. Two of them go to school. The older children got pregnant and dropped out of school. She owns a one-room house where she lives with three people. Janet also takes care of additional family members. The family has no access to electricity or piped water, but gets three meals a day. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and medication.

Janet has been in her business for over ten years, and with MCDT for 12 years – now on her 20th loan working with the same group mates. Janet joined MCDT because it is near her home and also because she likes working in groups. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, a sack of rice, Irish potatoes and maize flour. She hopes to see her business get bigger and to start an outside catering section.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for her restaurant like bananas, Irish potatoes, rice and maize flour

loans.name: Florinda Fabiao

texts.pt:
Florinda Fabião C. nasceu no distrito da Manhiça, província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, tem 34 anos de idade, casada mãe de 4 filhos de 16,9,6 e 3 anos, os 3 mais velhos vão a escola. Fez somente 6ª classe não continuou devido ao casamento pré maturo. Vive na casa própria com os seus filhos em Boane. O marido trabalha na Republica da Africa do sul como serralheiro, para alem dos filhos não sustenta mais ninguém.

Saiu da Manhica com a sua família para Boane onde desenvolve o seu negócio há mais de 5 anos, vendendo produtos de primeira necessidade. Aprendeu a fazer Esta actividade sozinha. Poupa no sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa (xitique) no valor de 2.000.00mt. O marido tem enviado dinheiro para o sustento da família.

Conheceu a Hluvuku – Adsema, através da sua cunhada, que também é cliente desta instituição e nunca teve outros empréstimos em outros bancos.
Este é o seu 2º empréstimo na Hluvuku no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, areia, ferro e outros) para dar continuidade com a sua obra, que vem construindo em fases. O crédito passado foi de 5.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.

Compromete se a pagar o crédito adequadamente, para poder aceder a mais empréstimos com objectivo futuro de concluir a sua casa, para oferecer melhores condições de habitação a sua família.
texts.en:
Florinda Fabião C. is from the District of Manhiça in Maputo, southern Mozambique. She is 34, married and the mother of four children ages 16, 9, 6 and 3, the three older ones go to school. She finished 6th grade but had to drop school due to an unexpected pregnancy. She lives in her own house with her children in Boane. Her husband works in South Africa as a locksmith and sends the family some money every month. She has her own business in Boane selling first necessity products, activity that she's been performing for the past 5 years. She learned the business all on her own. Florinda is asking for a U$350 loan, which she'll use to buy construction supllies (cement, sand, iron and others) to finish buildng her house and provide her family with better life conditions.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de material de construcao ( cimento, areia e outros)

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
Narcisa B. works in someone else's sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She is 40 years old, widowed and has five school-age children. They are from the village of Tagoloan, Misamis Oriental. Narcisa has been in this business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2008, Narcisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Narcisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to to purchase products to sell. Narcisa is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her fourth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Abanya

texts.en:
Abanya E. is currently in the business of selling charcoal in the market and is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell.  Abanya is 35 years old and is married with a husband that is a soldier. She has four children, and her children go to school.  With the extra profit from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Keav

texts.en:
Keav P. is a married mother blessed with five children. Two of them are married and two others are learning in the local public school. She is a sacrificing and determined woman who tries to earn money to ensure her children attain the highest level of education. 

To earn a living, she sells fresh fish in the busy market. In order to help provide for the family, her husband works as a Khmer musician. The family's living situation is not so comfortable due to the state of their home. Because of this, Keav P. would like to seek a Kiva loan to pay a bill for repairing her old house.

loans.use: To pay a bill for repairing her old house

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Hog raising is the main source of income for Marilou's family. She is married to Edwin, who is a carpenter within their village. The couple is blessed with five children, namely: Ednalyn-16 years old, high school student; Analyn-14 years, high school student; Arlene-8 years old, second grade pupil; Jerwin-7 years old, first grade pupil; and John Jeric-2 years old. The couple wants their children to finish their schooling, that’s why they are striving hard for them to provide for their needs. 

Marilou needs funds for her hog raising business. In this regard, she is requesting a loan amounting to Php5,000 for the feed and maintenance of her pigs and some will be used for the repair of the pigs' pen. She is really praying that lenders will grant her request.

loans.use: additional capital for hog raising business

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy L. is 45 years old, married, and presently residing at Lobogon, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She has four school-aged children.

Juvy’s husband is a fisherman and this is their primary source of income. Her husband's catch is sold to public market or to their neighbors. Their fishing activity sustains their daily needs despite the weather conditions.

In 2000, Juvy decided to join Paglaum Multi-purpose Cooperative (PMPC) to gain access to financial services to help improve their daily living by receiving a loan from PMPC. She is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase fish to sell because her husband isn’t making a a good catch.

Since joining PMPC, Juvy is now on her 6th regular loan. In the future, she looks forward to owning a stall in the public market where she can display her fish.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Patricio Justino

texts.pt:
Patrício Justino N. nasceu em Homoine, na província de Inhambane, sul de Moçambique, tem 39 anos de idade, casado e pai de 7 filhos de 17,17,12,10,4,4 e 2 anos de idade, deste 5 vão a escola. Fez somente 2ª classe, não continuou devido a guerra que assolou o pais, assim foi recrutado para fazer parte da força militar. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta a sua mãe enviando lhe géneros alimentícios.

Saiu de Inhambane para Boane em 1986, quando foi recrutado pelo Ministério da defesa, depois de desmobilizado, decidiu continuar como quadro deste Ministério. Mais tarde veio a sua família ao encontro do marido em Boane. Tem um rendimento mensal de 3.000.00mt, poupa algum valor no banco comercial BARCLAYS.

Nunca teve empréstimos com outras instituições financeiras, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seu colega que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 9.000.00mt, com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, porta, aros de portas e outros) para dar continuidade com a sua obra. Os anteriores empréstimos foram de 4.000.00mt e 7.000.00mt todos para a mesma actividade.

No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos, para concluir a sua obra e fazer um murro de vedação, como forma de dar melhor comodidade a sua família.
texts.en:
Patrício Justino N. is from Homoine, Inhambane province, south of Mozambique. He is 39 years old, married and the father of seven children ages 17, 17, 12, 10, 4, 4 and 2. Five of them go to school. Patricio only studied until 2nd grade, when the war hit the country and he was forced to join the military. He lives in his own house with his family and supports his mother by sending her food and money. He makes U$102 per month working for the Ministry of Defense, and supports his family with that money. He is asking for a U$325 loan in order to buy construction supplies (cement, doors, and others) so he can finish his house and give his family a more comfortable life.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction Supplies

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en: Rosie B. is from the town of Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. Rosie owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. In 2008, Rosie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. Rosie is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other needed supplies. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy feed for her piglets and other needed supplies

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa has a small stall where she sells different commodities such as fruits, vegetables, meat, chicken and so on. She gets her vegetable products at her family's small farm. She generates an income of at least Php2,500 monthly and she wishes to expand her business to be able to have more profit. She hopes for a loan of PHP5,000 for the development of her business. She hopes that lenders will help her improve her family's standard of living through giving her the chance to improve her business. She hopes that her loan will be granted. 

Elsa is 52 years old and married to Rolando, an auto-electrician. They have two adult children. Their family lives in the village of Palattao, Naguilian, Isabela. Now that the couple is merely supporting themselves, they hope to improve their living condition with the help of their businesses.

loans.use: additional capital to extend her food market business

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina A. is from the village of  Tagoloan, Iligan City. She is 31 years old. Gina is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Gina ownsand operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling ready-to-wear products in the local community. Gina has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Gina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Gina is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Gina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a 36-year-old married woman with five children, aged between 3 and 10 years old. All her children go to school. She owns a five-room house where she lives with seven people. In addition, she takes care of other family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

She doesn’t incur transport costs to buy charcoal because she buys from delivery vans that pick up the charcoal from the villages and then deliver it directly to her home. She works in a semi-urban area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a charcoal store in Kisaasi in Nsimbi Ziwoome zone. She sells both retail and wholesale. Sarah works seven days a week and receives an average of 25 customers a day. Besides her charcoal business, she also sells Airtime. Her major business challenges include thieves, ever increasing charcoal prices, the rainy season which hinders her customers from reaching her, and even the cost of transporting the charcoal.

Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and supplying medication. She has been in this business for over fifteen years and has been associated with MCDT for twelve years. Sarah is requesting her thirtieth loan, working with the same group mates. Sarah joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because she likes working in groups. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She is aspires to grow her business so she can sell wholesale only.

loans.use: Buy sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en:
Ellen C. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 24 years old. Ellen is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Ellen owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling eggs in the local community. Ellen has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ellen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Ellen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Ellen is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second taken out by Ellen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her retail business

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Jalia

texts.en:
Jalia is a 40-year-old married woman with six children aged between 4 and 22 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a six-room house where she lives with seven people. Jalia takes care of additional family members.The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. 

She incurs transportation costs to and from Owino market. She works in a semi-urban area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a shop selling second-hand clothes in Kisasi Kikulu zone. She sells both retail and wholesale. Jalia works seven days a week. She receives an average of 20 customers a day. 

She also owns a charcoal business and rental rooms.  Her major business challenges include thieves and ever-increasing prices of second-hand clothes. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and medication.  She has been in this business for more than six years and with MCDT for 10 years. This is her 20th loan working with the same group. Jalia joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because of working in groups to secure loans. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and start selling wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more second-hand clothes

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en:
Nuon N. is 58 years old, married and a mother. She currently works for a cleaning company, while her husband is a domestic construction worker. Nuon N. has six children, three of whom are married and live independently and the three who are single and employed. 

Nuon N. and her husband are facing difficulties with their living situation because the spare part of their house need repair. Because of that, Nuon N. is applying for a US$500 loan to pay the cost of repairing her existing house. 

Note: Nuon N. was busy at her work, so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To pay the cost of repairing her existing house

loans.name: Leonor

texts.en: Leonor U. is from the village of Ibabao. She is 51 years old, is married, and has five adult children. Leonor and her husband own and operate a furniture-making business, making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2000, Leonor joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Leonor is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This loan will be her 17th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Lynn

texts.en:
Lynn B. is from the village of Libertad, Misamis Oriental. She is 22 years old. Lynn is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Lynn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Lynn has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lynn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lynn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Lynn is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Lynn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet R. is from the village of Dullan. She is 32 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Juliet and her husband own and operate a quarrying business, selling sand and gravel in the local community. Juliet has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2005, Juliet joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is a 62-year-old single mother of six children aged between 30 and 40 years. None of her children go to school. She resides in and owns a six-room house where she lives with four people. Imelda takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. 

She incurs transportation costs to and from buying food stuff at Owino market. She works in a semi-urban area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a restaurant selling all types of food in Lubaga Road Kitawuluzi  Zone. She sells both on retail and wholesale. Imelda works six days a week. She receives an average of 30 customers a day.

Her major business challenges include ever-increasing prices of food. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and medication.  She has been in this business for more than six years and with MCDT for seven years. This is her 20th loan working with the same group. Imelda joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because of working in groups to secure loans. She wants to use this loan to buy more food, such as bananas, potatoes, cassava and beans. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and eventually start a catering firm.

loans.use: To buy more food like bananas, cassava, potatoes and beans

loans.name: Reygie

texts.en:
Reygie A. is from the village of Tagpangi, a part of Cagayan de Oro City on the southern island of Mindanao. She is 30 years old, married and has three school-aged children. Reygie owns a sari-sari (variety) shop from which she sells both food and products for daily use to the local community as her new business. Reygie has been in business for over five years, before she engaged into buying and selling of fruits in their village and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Reygie joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. Reygie is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP, her fourth loan from HSPFI, to invest in her new  business the sari sari store. She recently finished repaying a loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to buy additional inventory . With the additional revenue generated from this loan, she plans to continue expanding her sari sari store business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

location.town: Tagpangi, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Ricky

texts.en:
Ricky is a 30-year-old farmer. He is married and has two children. He tills his own farm and works hard for his family. He wants to save for the future of his children who are still very young. His oldest child is only one year old.

Ricky joined CEVI, as he needs agricultural supplies for his farm. He is now requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP. He will use this loan to purchase fertilizer and other supplies his farm needs.

loans.use: To purchase farming supplies

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita B. is 45 years old and living in Cagayan Province on the island of Luzon; her home is in Barangay Baculud in Iguig Municipality. She is happily married and has four children. They are Jayson, 21 years old and of college age; Karen Joy, sixteen years old and a college student studying information technology; Jhon-Jhon, twelve years old and a grade VI pupil; and Jerico, seven years old and a grade I pupil.

Estelita manages her store while her husband is a farmer in their village. Since her husband does not have regular work, she started her own business to provide another source of income. Together they are helping one another meet the needs of their family.

Estelita wants her business to improve, and this is the reason why she is asking to borrow 5,000 PHP from KIVA lenders through Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc. (ASKI). She plans to buy more commodities to offer to her customers. She is hoping that her business will continue to improve for the sake of the future of her children.

loans.use: To buy additional commodities to sell in her village store

loans.name: Rosalyn

texts.en: 37-year-old Rosalyn B. is a married woman. She lives on rice farming and learned to love doing it. Rice farming is her source of income. She does her best to keep the farm in good condition because she does not want to fail again. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and asked for a loan of 12,000 PHP. This loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farming necessities.

loans.use: Fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Damdinsuren

texts.en:
Damdinsuren B. is 44 years old and lives with his wife and two children in a house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His two children, 14 and 10 years old, both attend a local secondary school while his wife stays at home. B. sells women’s handbags in the largest Ulaanbaatar market, Narantuul. He began his business in 2000 after working as a geologist for a period of time. He purchases bags from China. B.’s working capital is 2,000,000 tugrugs and he has a healthy business profit of between 20% and 30% of that each month. He is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more handbags and increase his working capital. XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more handbags and increase his working capital

loans.name: Jean

texts.en: Jean is a married woman. She is 37 years old and has three kids. Her eldest child is only twelve. She does rice farming for a living. According to Jean, her rice crops are growing well but still need additional inputs. To supply her needs, she applied for a loan of 12,000 PHP from the Kiva field partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. Jean will use this loan to purchase necessary farming supplies and she is hopeful that this loan will truly help her achieve an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farming Supplies

loans.name: Osita

texts.en:
Osita M. is from the village of Opol, Misamis Oriental. She is 58 years old. Osita is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Osita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. She sells both food and daily use products in the local community. Osita has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $218 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Osita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Osita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Osita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 2nd loan  from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Chadi

texts.en:
Chadi is a 31-year-old man who lives in Saida in southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Chadi has been working as a furniture painter since 1989. He repairs old furniture and even manufactures new furniture. He does bedrooms, living rooms, any rooms that need furniture.

Chadi requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a new wood machine for his work. Chadi has been a micro-credit client for ten years now and has always paid on time.

Chadi is unique in his work because he knows how to treat his clients and always does a good job. His clients are his friends, neighbors and referrals. When he first started his business, he had difficulty building networking with clients and had some financial issues. Chadi originally decided to start this business because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans to expand his business, and he also wants to open a grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase a new wood machine for his work.

loans.name: Sandag-Ochir

texts.en:
Sandag-Ochir E. is 46 years old and lives with her husband and six children in a house in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia’s capital city. Her husband runs a taxi service; her two oldest children each own their own businesses, her four youngest children all attend a local secondary school, and E. operates a retail clothing business. She began her business in 2000 and operates it out of a stall in Narantuul, Ulaanbaatar’s largest outdoor market.

Over the past nine years, E. has proven to be a very hard-working entrepreneur with a lot of business and customer service experience. Currently, her working capital exceeds 2 million tugrugs (and she operates with a profit margin of 30%). She hopes that when the time comes, she and her husband will be able to afford to send all of their children to university, where they can learn how to improve their own lives and the lives of others. E. is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (approx. $1013 USD) loan in order to purchase more clothing for her business and to increase her working capital. XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing for her business and increase her working capital

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah is 42 years old and married with four children between 24 and 18 years of age. All her children go to school. The first two are at university, while the third and fourth born are in senior six and five. Norah owns a six-room house where she lives with six people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

She incurs transportation costs to and from buying second-hand clothes from Owino market. She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a shop in Ntinda Bukoto 11. Parish, where she sells all types of used clothing. She sells both retail and wholesale.

Norah works seven days a week, receiving an average of thirty customers a day. Her major challenges include the ever-increasing price of groceries. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and medication.

She has been in this business for over eighteen years, and with MCDT for ten years, now servicing her 20th loan working with the same group mates. Norah joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because she preferred working in groups.

She wants to use this loan to buy more used clothing to sell. She hopes to see her business grow bigger so she could start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more second hand clothes

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en: Mr. Saroeun C. is a villager in Prey Chheu Teal Village in Takeo province. He is a pig breeder. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it by purchasing two more piglets and pig food for breeding. He hopes to increase income and improve the family's standard of living with this loan. His wife, Mrs. Neang You, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Mr. Saroeun C. is a father of three children who are all attending the local school. His wife appears on the right side of the photo.

loans.use: To buy two more piglets and pig food for breeding

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn M. is from the village of Opol, Misamis Oriental. She is 34 years old and married with five school-aged children. To make a living, Merlyn owns and operates a specialized retail store where she sells seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community.  Merlyn is just starting this business. Previously she had a trisikad to transport passengers in their village (a "pedicab" or bicycle with a side-attached rider seat),

In 2009, Merlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Merlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This  will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to continue to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Twegate Bugonja Rose Group

texts.en: B. Rose is a hardworking business lady, aged twenty-five years, married and blessed with one child. B. Rose owns a grocery store selling bananas, onions, tomatoes, charcoal, and so forth since 2007. She is using this loan to purchase grocery items; for instance, she will be able to purchase over thirty bags of charcoal, where previously she could purchase only ten bags of charcoal. She is working very hard to improve upon her business so that she can raise her standard of living and build a house for her son, too.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items to sell

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap K. is a villager in Chuos village in Takeo province. She has four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

Mrs. Sopheap K. is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. She also raises pigs. Since raising pigs is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fifteen piglets to raise and pig food.

loans.use: To buy fifteen piglets and pig food

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 37-year-old man who lives in Saida in southem Lebanon with his wife and their one child. Ali has been working as a taxi driver since 2000. Ali requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase a new car. This new car will provide him some additionA. revenue because he plans to rent it. This is the fourth cycle and he has always paid on time.

Ali is good at his work because he knows how to treat his clients. They are his friends, neighbors and passers-by. When he first started his business, he didn’t own a car, so he had to rent one. That cost him a lot and didn’t allow him to save money. Before he started working as a taxi driver, he used to work as a school bus driver, but he decided to find independent work and started working as a taxi driver.

loans.use: To purchase a new car.

loans.name: Arshak

texts.en:
Arshak S. is 35 years old. He lives in Ijevan with his wife and 2 school-age daughters. Arshak’s wife is a housewife. Arshak has had his own business for 16 years. He rents a shop, where he sells food and household goods. With the income from his business Arshak was able to repair his house, buy furniture, and care for his family.

To increase his business income, Arshak is requesting a 1.000.000 AMD loan to buy an assortment of New Year’s products for his shop, like candied fruits, raisins, nuts, candy, and beverages.

loans.use: Purchase assortment of New Year’s products

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is a 35-year-old single mother of five children, aged between 7 and 15 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a two-roomed house where she is staying with three people. Victoria takes care of additional family members.The family has access to electricity but no piped water; they get three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying second-hand clothes from Nakawa market.

Victoria works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a shop selling all types of second-hand clothes in Naguru Go- Down Zone. She sells both retail and wholesale. Victoria works seven days a week .She receives an average of 30 customers a day. Her major business challenges include ever increasing prices for second-hand clothes . Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and medication.

Victoria has been in this business for over ten years and with MCDT for five years, servicing her tenth loan, working with the same group-mates. Victoria joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because of working in groups. She wants to use this loan to buy more second-hand clothes. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and starting selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more sexcond-hand clothes for sale

loans.name: Nakry

texts.en: Mrs. Nakhry C. is villager in Prambei Mom village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Nop Chanthea, is a motorbike taxi driver who can make a small income to support the family and now he faces a problem because his motorbike is too old and he spends a lot of money to buy fuel to support the motorbike. Thus, Mrs. Nakhry C. decided to ask for a loan to replace the motorbike for her husband to save more money. Mrs. Nakhry C. has two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the younger is only one year old. Her husband is on the left with the child.

loans.use: Replace the motorbike for her husband to save more money.

loans.name: Kamel

texts.en:
Kamel is a 50-year-old man who lives in Saida, Southem Lebanon, with his wife and four children. Kamel has been selling roasters and charcoal for 29 years. He has requested a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua in order to purchase a roaster for his work. Kamel has been a micro-credit client for five years now and has always repaid on time.

Kamel is successful in his work because he charges competitive prices and sells his products wholesale. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Kamel set up this business because he wanted to be independent in his work, and there is high customer demand in his region. In future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase a roaster

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en:
Vicky O. is from the village of Opol, Misamis Oriental. She is 35 years old. Vicky is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Vicky owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp. Vicky has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Vicky joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and enable her to engage in business activities. Vicky is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Vicky from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sari

texts.en: Mrs. Sari P. is a villager in Krang Touch village in Takeo province. She is farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, she is a pig breeder. Since her breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing eight more piglets and pig food. Her husband, Mr. Suon Chok, is a motorbike taxi driver who can make a small income to support the family. Mrs. Sari P. has three children who all are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy eight more piglets and pig food

loans.name: Choun

texts.en: S., 54, is a married woman and the mother of six children. Three of them are married and the remainder are single and work as garment workers. To earn a living, S. buys silk skirts in bulk on credit from a silk weaver and then she sells them from door-to-door around Phnom Penh. She and her husband also cultivate crops. Because S. sees that her business is the main way for her to generate much income, she would like to request a loan from Kiva to order more silk skirts to sell.

loans.use: To order more silk skirts to sell

loans.name: Puth

texts.en:
Mr. Puth P. lives in Prey Chheu Teal village in Takeo province. He and his wife, Mrs. Neth Reth, are farmers who own a 2-hecater field of land to cultivate rice. Although this couple tries to work hard, they still earn little income to support the family. Thus, Mr. Puth P. decided to ask for a loan to buy 2 cows for breeding.

Mr. Puth P. has 6 children two of whom are sellers and the others are attending the local school. His wife is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy 2 cows for breeding.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 23-year-old man who lives in Saida, Southem Lebanon, with his wife and their child. Ahmad has been working as a carpenter for five years. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase wood for his work. This is the first time that Ahmad has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.
Ahmad is special in his work because he does it well. His clients are his friends, neighbors and traders. When he first started his business, he didn’t have enough cash to have all the required tools. Ahmad decided to do this business because he wanted to have independent work, and it is in demand in his region. In future, he plans to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase wood for his work.

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy M. is now 50 years old and married to a responsible man, Remelio M.. In order to support the needs of their 2 children, Cristina and Justine, her husband works abroad as a seaman. Remelio suffers from being away from his family in order to sustain their needs because now they have more expenses for the education of their children; sending children to college is very expensive. Both children are now in college, the older one taking up nursing and the second, mechanical engineering. In order to help her husband in providing for their family, Daisy runs a sewing business. She sews curtains that she sometimes sells or sometimes customers order from her. This business has operated for 18 years now and and hopefully will continue to grow. Through the money that she saves they been able to buy their own tricycle (type of cab in the Philippines that has a three wheels), and the revenue from it also contributes to their income.

When she became a member of Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), the loan that she received was a big help in improving her sewing business and its revenue really helps for their big expenses. Now, her 12th loan will be used to improve this business. She will buy all the necessary things that are needed so that her business will be more productive.

One dream of Daisy's is that their children will finish their studies, because she believes that education is one of the keys to having a better life in the future. Daisy hoping that her business will continue to grow and someday she can have her own dress shop to generate enough income so that her husband has no need to go abroad to provide for them.

loans.use: To finance her sewing business

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou D. est âgée de 29 ans, elle est marié et mère de 04 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KANDE BANETO depuis un an et demi et y a eu de bonnes performances. Avec son prêt elle développe une activité de vente de légumes et les bénéfices générés lui permettront de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Fatou D. is 29 years old, married, and the mother of four. She has been a member of Banc Villageois de KANDE BANETO for 1½ years and has had a good record there. With her loan, she is developing a business selling vegetables. The profits generated will allow her to help improve her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster her business selling vegetables

loans.name: Sareth

texts.en: Mrs. Sareth C. lives in Angkonh village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Long Neang, is a cow breeder.  Since this business is going well he wants to expand it so his wife decide to ask for a loan to buy two more cows for breeding. Mrs. Sareth C. has six children, four of whom are employed in different positions and the others are studying. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy two more cows for breeding.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna S. is from the village of Talakag Bukidnon. She is 49 years old. Lorna is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lorna owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lorna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and engage in business activities. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Lorna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 25, the single mother of two children aged 3 and 10 years. Both of her children go to school. She owns a two-roomed house where she lives with two people. Catherine takes care of additional family members.The family has no access to electricity and piped water, but they get three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying vegetables from Nakawa market. She works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala.

She owns a stall selling vegetables in Naguru Go-Down Zone. She sells both at retail and wholesale. Catherine works seven days a week. She receives an average of 10 customers a day. Her major business challenges include ever-increasing prices of vegetables. Her monthly expenses include and feeding the family and medication. She has been in this business for over five years and with MCDT for five years, servicing her tenth loan working with the same group-mates. Catherine joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because of working in groups. She wants to use this loan to buy more baskets of vegetables like tomatoes, cabbages, onions, eggplants, etc. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and start selling at wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of taomatoes, onions, cabbages, and eggplants

loans.name: Mrs. Sdeurng Ngay Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sdeurng N. lives in Chrouy village in Takeo province: she is the group leader of four people who all live in this village. Mrs. Sdeurng N. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Sam Dara, is a fisherman who earns a small income to support the family. Although they try to work hard they still earn less than the income needed to support the family.

Thus, Mrs. Sdeurng N. is requesting a loan to buy a cow for breeding to earn income. She is the mother of three children, two of whom are attending the local school while the other child, aged five years old, is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding to earn income.

loans.name: Mr. Bol Va Group

texts.en:
Mr. Bol V. is the group leader of four people who all live in Thum village in Takeo province. He and his wife are farmers and they also are egg sellers. Since this business is going well, they want to expand it so he decided to ask for a loan to buy more eggs to re-sell.

Mr. Bol V. is the father of two children who are both too young to work or study because they are at the age of three and five years old.

loans.use: To buy more age to re-sell

loans.name: Mrs. Moeurn Chen Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Moeurn C. is the village bank president of a group of twelve people and they all live in Srae Thlok village in Takeo province. The members in this village will each use their loan for a different purpose.

For instance, Mrs. Moeurn C. is a duck breeder and she will use the loan to buy more duck food to support her ducks. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family’s living conditions with this loan.

Mrs. Moeurn C. is the mother of three children who are all attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Ngaet Eak, is a farmer who owns a plot of land he uses to cultivate rice.

loans.use: To buy more duck food for her ducks

loans.name: Fatou Moussa

texts.fr: Fatou Moussa M. est une femme de 49 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 8 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KANDE BANETO depuis 7 ans et demi. Avec son prêt elle achète des bananes en gros pour revendre au détail dans le quartier. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de participer au bien-être de sa famille.
texts.en:
Fatou Moussa M., age 40, is married and the mother of 8 children. She's been a member of the village bank of Kande Baneto for seven and a half year. With this loan, she will buy bananas wholesale, and retail them in her neighborhood. Her profits will enable her to contribute to her family's well-being.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bananas

loans.name: Juliet  Keimrembe‘S Group

texts.en:
Juliet is 30 and married with four children between 3 and 12 years old. All her children go to school. She owns a two-roomed house where she lives with seven people. Juliet takes care of additional family members.The family has access to electricity but no piped water, and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying clothing materials from Kiyembe shops in Kampala city. She works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala.

Juliet owns a tailoring shop in Katanga in Wandegeya She sells both at retail and wholesale. Juliet works seven days a week. She receives an average of five customers a day. Her major business challenges include ever-increasing prices of clothing materials and the rainy season which disturbs her work because she works from a muddy place. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and medication. She has been in this business for over five years and with MCDT for four years, servicing her tenth loan working with the same group-mates. Juliet joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because of working in groups. She wants to use this loan to buy more rolls of clothing materials. She aspired to see her business grow bigger and start a tailoring school.

loans.use: To buy more clothing materials

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie B. is now 50 years old married to Ernesto B., now working as driver for one of the families in their area. They have six children: Eilyn, 21; Ma. Layne, 19; Merilyn, 18; Laarnies, 15; Errol, 12 and John Ernie, 10. Most of their children are now currently studying, so there are more expenses for their education. Aside from the salary of her husband, she also buys and sells secondhand appliances, frozen foods, and rice as the sources of their income. They need to work hard to pay the expenses of their big family.

She joined Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) in 1999, and since she became a member of this institution their life started to change. Her business continues to grow because every loan that she received is properly used, and she been able to send her other children to college and some of them have finished already. That is why she is very thankful to ASHI. Now her 12th loan will be use to improve her secondhand appliances business; she will buy different secondhand appliances for resale. She is hoping that this will help her business to grow more.

Now she is just praying that her business will continue to improve for her to be able to send all of her children to college. And she assures ASHI that she will work hard so that the chances that they give her will never be wasted.

loans.use: For buying of different secondhand appliances for her buy and sell business

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is 30 and married with two children, 3 and 12 years old. Both of her children go to school. She rents a one-roomed house where she is staying with four people. Aisha takes care of additional family members.The family has access to electricity but no piped water, and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs for buying clothing materials and foodstuffs from Nakawa market. She works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala.

She owns a stall in Naguru market selling bananas, cassava, sweet potatoes and Irish potatoes. Aisha works seven days a week. She receives an average of 25 customers a day. Her major business challenges include ever-increasing prices of foodstuffs and the rainy season, which disturbs her work because she works from a muddy place. Her monthly expenses include rent, monthly market dues, feeding the family and medication. She has been in this business for over three years and with MCDT for five years, servicing her tenth loan working with the same group-mates. Aisha joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because of working in groups. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, sacks of cassava, and sweet potatoes. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and start buying directly from farmers.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas,sweet potatoes cassavaand Irish potatoes

loans.name: Satenik

texts.en: Satenik G. lives in Yerevan and her only son lives and works in Russia. She worked in the National Library as a librarian until 1996. Then she rented place at the trade fair and began her business. She sells women’s and men’s clothes: blouses, pullovers, dresses and jackets. With the income of her business, Satenik was able to repair her apartment. She wants $3,000 to buy winter clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy winter clothes to sell

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Mr. Roberto E., 62 years old, is a married man and has one child who is now eighteen years old.

Roberto’s livelihood has been rice farming since 1990. He trained himself to know the strategies required in farming so he could produce quality rice crops. He also sought the help of Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a microfinance institution in the Philippines.

Now Roberto is requesting to loan Php 12,000 that he will use to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies needed at his farm.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Evelyn L. has been married to her husband Alan since 1994. They are blessed with five children, the eldest of whom is only thirteen years old.

Evelyn is a rice farmer. She learned the basics of farming through the help of her husband. Together, they plant and harvest rice on their farm.

To support her farming, Evelyn joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and appreciates the financial assistance offered to farmers like her. Now she is requesting to loan Php 12,000 which will go to farm inputs like fertilizers and also to pay the laborers who helped at her farm.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and to pay laborers

loans.name: Khulafai Primary School Group

texts.en:
These are some of the teachers of the Khulafai Primary School, located in Makeni, a town in Northern Sierra Leone. The school serves a total of 805 students (338 boys, 467 girls) and employs 23 teachers. In operation for 12 years, it receives a small annual stipend from the government to help cover its operating costs (very few schools in Sierra Leone are funded exclusively by the government). The school reports many successes, including the fact that the external (national) exam scores for their pupils have been steadily increasing thanks in large part to the teachers' hard work. For many of the teachers here, however, life can be a struggle. The school has fallen into disrepair, and there are no funds available to build additional classrooms, repair walls, replace broken desks, or make other necessary adjustments. Furthermore, many teachers' salaries are long overdue, with some that have waited over two years to receive a paycheck. Many teachers engage in side-projects and small businesses in order to supplement (or in some cases replace) their salaries, and Khulafai's teachers are collectively seeking a loan of SLL 11 million from SMT and Kiva Lenders.

Momodu K. (pictured second from right, back row) is a senior teacher at the school and has taken on the role of group leader. Momodu is 46 years old and has been teaching young children for 25 years. He is married to a petty trader, and together they have eight children (three boys and five girls). Five of Momodu's children attend school and three are not yet old enough. Some time ago, he purchased a plot of land on which he dreamed of building a house for his family because he believes that "once you own a home, you have something for which you and your family can be proud." He plans to use his portion of the funds to finance the purchase of some materials so that he can begin construction.

loans.use: Construction of a family home on already-purchased land

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en: Fifty-nine-year-old Catalina is a rice farmer who, despite being single, enjoys laboring at her farm. While her business is going well, the farm still lacks inputs, so she is requesting a loan of Php12,000 from CEV. Catalina will use this loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies and also to pay the laborers at her farm.

loans.use: Farm Inputs

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en: Ludmila, who is married with one child, sells men's clothing at the central market in Melitopol city. Ludmila has been in this business for 12 years, and during that time has developed her business well. She currently has three business locations and many repeated clients, and her goal is to open a small store to sell clothing. Ludmila would like to borrow 15,000 UAH to purchase seasonal inventories, hoping to thereby increase sales and move closer to achieving her business goal.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal inventories

loans.name: Mahmadsaid

texts.en:
